nodes.bodyText:
If pending > 0 then we are not writing the current request.
Plz add an explanation about the subtle meaning of this condition:
"Protocol inbound closing for a client is when a response is read, which decrements the pending count before reading the inbound closure signal. This means if pending > 0 there are more requests pending responses but the peer has signalled close. We need to abort write for pending requests"

This name and comment isn't indicating the intent of this event.
AbortWritesEvent is a better name that correctly indicates what we are doing at the moment.

Till now these events represented things that happened on the socket or what is exposed on the Close handler APIs. ChannelOutputClosingEvent is an event generated by the CloseHandler itself. Can we avoid expanding scope of events here? Instead validate/simulate things that will happen on the socket, like aborting writes.

nodes.bodyText:
closeReason isn't volatile so this may never see the closeReason.
Instead of using closeReason here use the new pipeline event to replace writableListener with a "poison value" that indicates abort writes and also aborts the current write if present.

Good catch!
I have to introduce another volatile boolean to prevent new writes because:

Can not reuse AbortWritesEvent because it's emitted only when there are additional requests in the pipeline. If there is no pipelining and all requests are sequential, it's not emitted => does not abort new writes.
Tried to reuse ProtocolPayloadEndEvent.OUTBOUND but it has a much broader scope (also used for h2) and fails a lot of tests.
Handling of "poison value" for channelOutboundListener complicates internal state management. It adds at least 2 volatile reads (1st in cleanupOnWriteTerminated, 2nd in failIfWriteActive) and complicates isWriteActive` implementation.
Discussed offline. Because closeReason is not on the hot path it's better just to make closeReason volatile instead of expanding internal state with another boolean.
